quizzes.title: History Quiz: Battleship and Word
quizzes.description: Test your history knowledge with this comprehensive quiz! Features 15 questions covering History, actor, mo. Includes 5 easy, 5 medium, and 5 challenging questions. Can you achieve a passing score of 70%?

questions.question: When did the famous American crooner Nat King Cole and his daughter Natalie Cole record their hit song, Unforgettable”?

options.text: The date was never officially revealed

questions.question: Born in Vladivostok, Russia in 1920, this Academy Award-winning actor is best know for playing King Mongkut of Siam 4,626 times onstage. He also reprised the role in the film version of the musical.
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Yul Brenner

questions.question: Nicknamed Mighty Mo (or Big Mo), this Iowa-class battleship from the end of World War II was the last battleship built by the United States.
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: USS Missouri

questions.question: Which of these Biblical characters is known to have the greatest number of children?
Having won 6 Tony Awards, including Best Musical, this 1950s production is a modern retelling of the Faust legend. Its main characters are Mr. Applegate, Joe Boyd and Lola.
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Damn Yankees

questions.question: Which word means a practitioner of the martial art of Okinawan origin, karate?
This is the only RB/soul singer asked by Johnny Carson to perform twice in the same week in The Tonight Show.
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Patti LaBelle

questions.question: Originally entitled Desert Song and released in 1972 by the band America, this song was banned in Kansas City for its supposed drug references.
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: A Horse with No Name

questions.question: This country is a founding member of the European Union and the United Nations and one of the five permanent members of the United Nations Security Council. It is visited by over 75 millions tourists annually.
British musician, singer, and songwriter Elvis Costello was born Declan Patrick Aloysius MacManus.

3M Company was formed in 1902 in Two Harbors, Minnesota near Lake Superior with the intent of selling sandpaper. The company made $22.923 billion USD in 2006 and is famous for several inventions, including Scotch tape. What does 3M stand for?
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Minnesota Mining and Manufacturing Company

questions.question: Which device was patented in 1970 by  Douglas Engelbart, an American inventor of Norwegian descent?
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: The computer mouse

questions.question: In what year did French mechanic Nicolas Joseph Cugnot invent the first self-propelled road vehicle?

In ancient times, which stone was believed to protect from drunkenness?

questions.question: Who invented the ball point pen?
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Jozsef Laszlo Biro

questions.question: Author Marianna Mayer describes this mythical creature as the only fabulous beast that does not seem to have been conceived out of human fears. In even the earliest references he is fierce yet good, selfless yet solitary, but always mysteriously beautiful. He could be captured only by unfair means. What creature is this?
The first couple to be shown in bed together on prime time television was this.
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Johnny and Mary Kay Stearns

questions.question: Former NBA coach Frank Layton once fined small forward Adrian Dantley thirty pieces of silver.  What did Layton say the fine was for?

options.text: Being late to three  practices in a row
Missing three foul shots in a row

questions.question: What was the first product to have a bar code?
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Wrigleys gum

questions.question: What do we call a storage place for bees?
Each king in a deck of playing cards represents a great king from history.
He was the only US President to win the Pulitzer Prize.
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: John F. Kennedy

questions.question: According to GlobalNet UK, less than what percentage of 500 Chinese cities surveyed have clean air?
This Shakespearean play is referred to as The Scottish Play or The Scottish King by most actors and theater people since it is considered bad luck to mention the name of the play.
The average person can live this number of days without water.
The idea of a helicopter was first documented by this man.
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Leonardo Da Vinci

quizzes.title: History Quiz: Bras and Bra

questions.question: Which of these elements has the highest melting point?

options.text: The Gunfight at the O.K. Corral

questions.explanation: The correct answer is: The Gunfight at the O.K. Corral

questions.question: What year did Mary Phelps Jacobs create the first modern bra after getting mad at her hard bodice? She covered its bones with silk handkerchief and attached it with a couple of cords.
King John Sobieski of Poland saved Vienna from Ottoman invaders. In his honor something new was invented.  What was it ?
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: The bagel

questions.question: What percentage of women do not wear the correct bra size?
Which President ended Reconstruction ?
A woman in the final stage of her pregnancy should not wear under-wired bras.
The average woman will wear different bra sizes in her life, due to gravity, pregnancy and weight changes. How many times will she change her size?
What year did the bra first appear?

Studies have proven that there is a relation between wearing bras and this disease.   Research found that 3 out of 4 women wearing bras 24 hours a day had the chance to get this disease, while women wearing bras for less than 12 hours a day had a 1 out of 152 chance.
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Breast cancer

questions.question: What price did someone pay for Marilyn Monroes bra that she wore in the 1959 movie Some Like It Hot?
How often should a woman change her bra?
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: every 6 months

questions.question: It has an unemployment rate  of 15%. According to the 2000 Census it is the poorest of   the 100 largest US Cities.  Which city is it?

options.text: Owls must turn their entire head to change views.
Owls are far-sighted and unable to clearly see within a few inches of their eyes.

questions.explanation: The correct answer is: All of these

questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Devils Sea

Lawrence Kusche was one of the first people to conduct a comprehensive research on the topic of strange disappearances of ships. His conclusions proved to some extent that there was nothing extraordinary about this region.  One of the following statements was not a conclusion that he made.

options.text: The number of such disappearances was exaggerated by sloppy research and fuzzy math.
The disappearance of three of the missing ships can be explained through the interference of the US Military Force.
The proportion of losses was no greater than anywhere else.
The number of ships which disappeared in supposedly still, calm weather, did not jibe with press weather reports published at the time.

questions.explanation: The correct answer is: The disappearance of three of the missing ships can be explained through the interference of the US Military Force.

questions.question: What is covered by the 19th amendment to the US constitution?

options.text: Voting rights for citizens of Washington, D.C.
Voting rights for people of Guam

questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Voting rights for women

options.text: He  was the only catcher to catch three no hitters.

questions.explanation: The correct answer is: He was an international spy.
